text: / mr. seniors decision not to take part
in this debate tonight a bit of a
metaphor for your whole campaign you're
very happy - repeatedly criticized the
Labour Party but for your own plans
you're reluctant to give us very much
detail at all whether that's on brexit
your future immigration system how many
people will lose your winter fuel
allowance you won't get me tell you now
what I've done in terms of our manifesto
it's been open with British people about
the great challenges that we face as a
country over the next few years and
beyond and how we will address those
challenges and you talk about the brexit
negotiations
I've sat out very clearly what our 12
objectives are for those four exit
negotiations I believe that's the right
thing to do as we go into those
negotiations which start just 11 days
after election day the question that
people must ask themselves on election
day is who do they want to see fighting
for Britain in those negotiations who do
they want to see taking this country
forward building a bored prosperous
Britain for the future the questions
that people also have it's about the
practical things that you would actually
do if you're re-elected so can you tell
us now how would the immigration system
work after a brexit who will lose their
winter fuel allowance where will you set
the social care cap because if you don't
there is this sense you are using these
slogans again and again you're talking
about your broad principles but your
type of hide behind that you won't tell
people what you'd actually do so we've
been very clear let's look at the issue
like the winter fuel payments and the
issue around social care what we've been
very clear with people about and open
with people about is that yes we do face
the pressures of an ageing society in
just 10 years time will be 2 million
more people aged over 75 in this country
and if we don't do something about our
social care system the system will
simply collapse so what we're proposing
is a system where people can protect
more savings to pass on to their
children where they won't have to sell
their home in their lifetime to pay for
their care bills so that worry will be
taken away from them and there will be a
cap on the absolute level if they had
how a minister is if you keep repeating
broad principles but don't give the
detail people will worry for example
that
millions of people might use their
winter fuel allowance or the cap on
social care might be set at an extremely
high level so people want more from you
because you're basically saying on many
of these big issues I'll get back to you
what I'm saying is I will listen to you
and I think that's important you can
approach this in one of two ways I set
out the broad principles of our policy
I've shown how we will provide a
sustainable long long-term sustainable
social care system for this country
which we need because the system will
clap unless we do something and do it
now but what I'm also saying to people
is I want to listen to them about where
that cap should be about where we should
means-test winter fuel payments listen
to voters listen to organizations
charities and others working with older
people consult with them I think that's
the open thing for a government to do
don't you think though that when it
comes to the decision that you're asking
voters to make that you owe it to them
as a politician who wants people to take
her at her word to give more precise
details on a whole range of things about
when you will bring immigration down
when you would keep that promise where
these caps will be on social policy
don't you think people deserve more I
think what we owe to people is to be
open with them about the challenges we
face as a society and of the country to
be open with them about the challenge of
the brexit negotiations about the
challenge of our aging society of
securing our economy for the future
which and we have been and be open with
them about the solutions that we're
offering and then I think I also owe it
to people to say yes in some of these we
will listen to you we will work with you
we will ensure that the details of what
we're doing if we announce after we've
consulted with people we're the party
that is showing that we have the
willingness to be open with people that
there are challenges ahead there are
hard choices ahead but we can grasp the
opportunities that are ahead for us as
well and I'm optimistic about the
opportunities that this country can have
for a better future because I believe in
Britain and I believe in the British
people it's finally in very briefly
Prime Minister you see repeatedly no
deal is better than a
a deal but you also say if we get bricks
it wrong the consequences would be dire
don't those few things contradict
themselves because it is a bad deal
you'd walk away if we if we get a bad
deal then it would be the consequences
would be very difficult for this country
and if you look at what a bad view might
be there are people in Europe who talk
about punishing the UK I think that
could lead to a bad deal and some
politicians in other parties here in the
UK who seem to want to be willing to
accept the deal whatever it is I think
that the Labour Party would look at
taking any deal at the highest price
they'd end up with a worse deal at the
highest price that's not good for our
future that's not about negotiating
brexit strong and stable leadership in
negotiating brexit is about getting the
right deal submission and the right deal
that can ensure we have a strong and
